text: I’ve read a few posts that suggest you can buy betfair data cheaper by going to bdp directly. I’ve started recording my own data but there’s a lead time to build up a decent database. Is my understanding correct? If so, any idea of the cost? Pro data for uk and aus dogs and horses is what I’m interested in.

That would be nice but I really wish they made it all free

Look at the wealth of data you can download from Binance: <https://www.binance.com/en/landing/data>. All free, not even a login required

text: Are barriers to entry a good or bad thing for existing professionals? I have a feeling exchange sports trading is probably too small scale for most successful people in financial trading

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Are barriers to entry a good or bad thing for existing professionals? I have a feeling exchange sports trading is probably too small scale for most successful people in financial trading

text:
1. IMVHO, we want as many people getting into the exchange as possible. Yes, they might be the next <@U01B8031PM1>, but for every one of him, there will be a lot who lose some money to us
2. I think sports betting is extremely attractive to traditional financial market traders although they might not realise it yet. Firstly, it's a great test bed for ideas that can ultimately be applied to financial markets. Secondly, it's something they can trade on the side that will have no conflicts of interest with their day job

text: I heard, from a friend with financial experience, that most trading firms get their PnL from a tiny number of strategies/alpha sources . And then have a load of breaken/minor losing strategies for research purposes. Have others experienced this?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: I heard, from a friend with financial experience, that most trading firms get their PnL from a tiny number of strategies/alpha sources . And then have a load of breaken/minor losing strategies for research purposes. Have others experienced this?

text: <@UBS7QANF3> I've heard you say #1 a few times but never understood it. How are you imagining it play out? It took me A LOT of time to get to profitability, but not much of any losses. I wouldn't have launched unless the backtests looked good. And of course initial launch was at min stakes. Are you imagining less disciplined aspiring traders who are launching without doing their due diligence?

elements.text: I've heard you say #1 a few times but never understood it. How are you imagining it play out? It took me A LOT of time to get to profitability, but not much of any losses. text: Aren't you just a case of survivorship bias?

elements.text: Aren't you just a case of survivorship bias?

text: Added on an edit you may not have seen. But basically I'm expected failed aspiring traders to not lose much in their failed attempt, as they would see negative results in a backtest. Or launch and see negative results at min stakes very quickly.

elements.text: Added on an edit you may not have seen. But basically I'm expected failed aspiring traders to not lose much in their failed attempt, as they would see negative results in a backtest. Or launch and see negative results at min stakes very quickly.

text: I agree...betting regularly via the API in a way that's noticeably profitable for existing participants means you need to be a) smart enough to actually start using the API enough and b) have enough cash to burn over an extended period and c) not get to that point where your flow becomes sharp. The intersection of all 3 is probably a small minority.

elements.text: I agree...betting regularly via the API in a way that's noticeably profitable for existing participants means you need to be a) smart enough to actually start using the API enough and b) have enough cash to burn over an extended period and c) not get to that point where your flow becomes sharp. The intersection of all 3 is probably a small minority.

text: IMO what would be most profitable is to encourage flow from the sportsbook to the exchange in a way that's transparent to the recreational participant

elements.text: IMO what would be most profitable is to encourage flow from the sportsbook to the exchange in a way that's transparent to the recreational participant

text:
Like you say, for one thing there is a question of discipline

Not everyone will have the skills, knowledge and discipline to avoid blowing up on their way to profitability. Perhaps some have the discipline but it takes them a long time and sizeable losses that we get to enjoy before they get there

Perhaps the backtest looks good but they don't understand market capacity so they give a lot back when they try to scale up

Perhaps they go live too quickly, lose £50 and never come back. All we need in that case is enough churn

Without putting too fine a point on it, you want to give them enough rope to hang themselves with

Perhaps they go live too quickly, lose £50 and never come back. All we need in that case is enough churn

Without putting too fine a point on it, you want to give them enough rope to hang themselves with

text: Perhaps I should have said contacting bsp directly instead of buying through the site. The wider debate is interesting and something I’ve been thinking about a lot recently. I’ve invested a lot of time in betting when that time could have been spent in other markets. There are some benefits to sports markets but of course capacity is much lower.

text: I reckon if you were able to plot pnl as a function of bet-source (e.g. how did your counterparty submit their bet), you'd find lowest chunk of pnl Vs other raw API participants, a large chunk from software such as BA/Guess etc and a large chunk from exchange website.

elements.text: I reckon if you were able to plot pnl as a function of bet-source (e.g. how did your counterparty submit their bet), you'd find lowest chunk of pnl Vs other raw API participants, a large chunk from software such as BA/Guess etc and a large chunk from exchange website.

text:
Remember my starting point is making the historic data freely available and as frictionless to get hold of as possible

I'm not even expecting all of the people this attracts to become API users. There are a lot of people out there who are interested in data analysis and coding who are looking for free data sets and things to do hobby projects on who may:

1. Never have had any interest in gambling or
2. Know Betfair operates an exchange or
3. Know that Betfair has an API
Again, all you would need is for some of these people to take an interest, play around on the site, lose £50 and never come back

I can't find a figure for Betfair's cost per acquisition in Flutter's latest annual results but based on previous reports, I think ~£200 is a reasonable ball park. Feels like my idea can easily be competitive with that. In short, I think the historic data would be much better used as marketing than its own revenue stream
